        Thanks. This will be my last comment, as although I don't think you'll be satisfied with the answer, it remains the correct answer.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks. This will be my last comment, as although I don't think you'll be satisfied with the answer, it remains the correct answer.<!----></span><br><br>OpenSSL is not a useful reference for certificate verification. It does not implement RFC 5280 (or 3280), nor does it implement path building. It is one of the worst references to use for "Internet" client applications, even though its perfectly serviceable as a server.<span class="line"><!---->OpenSSL is not a useful reference for certificate verification. It does not implement RFC 5280 (or 3280), nor does it implement path building. It is one of the worst references to use for "Internet" client applications, even though its perfectly serviceable as a server.<!----></span><br><br>Chrome uses different verification stacks on different platforms, so the differences are expected (as covered in the issue I liked to in <span class="line"><!---->Chrome uses different verification stacks on different platforms, so the differences are expected (as covered in the issue I liked to in <!----></span>Comment #12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->Comment #12<!----></a> and other issues).<span class="line"><!----> and other issues).<!----></span><br><br>Name Constraints don't work like you would like them to, nor have they ever. I can understand this may be surprising and disappointing, but this is perfectly defined, specified behavior. If you install the root certificate, you are trusting the certificates that CA issues. I realize you'd like to only be able to trust "some" of the certificates that CA issues, and that's why <span class="line"><!---->Name Constraints don't work like you would like them to, nor have they ever. I can understand this may be surprising and disappointing, but this is perfectly defined, specified behavior. If you install the root certificate, you are trusting the certificates that CA issues. I realize you'd like to only be able to trust "some" of the certificates that CA issues, and that's why <!----></span>Issue 1072083<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1072083" title="Feature request: Support constraints on user-imported roots"><!---->Issue 1072083<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>is a feature request, but as it stands, and broadly, as it stands in a variety of applications, installing a CA is just that: trusting everything.<span class="line"><!---->is a feature request, but as it stands, and broadly, as it stands in a variety of applications, installing a CA is just that: trusting everything.<!----></span><br><br>Since you're upset about Android behaviour, you'll also be upset to learn that it doesn't respect anything else from the root certificate, including expiration. That, as I covered, is well-defined, well-specified behavior, and the fault is on the client for expecting a different behavior. This same behaviour, which you would find undesired, also helps improve the security of users. For example, see <span class="line"><!---->Since you're upset about Android behaviour, you'll also be upset to learn that it doesn't respect anything else from the root certificate, including expiration. That, as I covered, is well-defined, well-specified behavior, and the fault is on the client for expecting a different behavior. This same behaviour, which you would find undesired, also helps improve the security of users. For example, see <!----></span>https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html"><!---->https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html<!----></a> that was only possible precisely because Android ignores the elements of the root certificates (including Chrome on Android).<span class="line"><!----> that was only possible precisely because Android ignores the elements of the root certificates (including Chrome on Android).<!----></span><br><br>While we may change in the future to support respecting these constraints, at the end of the day, this is not a bug, and certainly not a security bug. Thanks for reporting, and sorry if this answer is dissatisfying.<span class="line"><!---->While we may change in the future to support respecting these constraints, at the end of the day, this is not a bug, and certainly not a security bug. Thanks for reporting, and sorry if this answer is dissatisfying.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

      UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.182 Safari/537.36<span class="line"><!---->UserAgent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/88.0.4324.182 Safari/537.36<!----></span><br><br>Steps to reproduce the problem:<span class="line"><!---->Steps to reproduce the problem:<!----></span><br>1. Create CA with name constraint (for example:<span class="line"><!---->1. Create CA with name constraint (for example:<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>joomdev.net<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joomdev.net"><!---->joomdev.net<!----></a>) - this CA can sign only certificates for<span class="line"><!---->) - this CA can sign only certificates for<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>joomdev.net<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://joomdev.net"><!---->joomdev.net<!----></a> subdomain (attached as trusted_ca_chain.crt);<span class="line"><!----> subdomain (attached as trusted_ca_chain.crt);<!----></span><br>2. Add CA with name constraint to browser;<span class="line"><!---->2. Add CA with name constraint to browser;<!----></span><br>3. Create cert and sign with this CA for fraud.bozaro.ru (attached as fraud_bozaro_ru_chain.crt);<span class="line"><!---->3. Create cert and sign with this CA for fraud.bozaro.ru (attached as fraud_bozaro_ru_chain.crt);<!----></span><br>4. Open <span class="line"><!---->4. Open <!----></span>https://fraud.bozaro.ru<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://fraud.bozaro.ru"><!---->https://fraud.bozaro.ru<!----></a><br><br>Manual for creating certificates by hands: <span class="line"><!---->Manual for creating certificates by hands: <!----></span>https://systemoverlord.com/2020/06/14/private-ca-with-x-509-name-constraints.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://systemoverlord.com/2020/06/14/private-ca-with-x-509-name-constraints.html"><!---->https://systemoverlord.com/2020/06/14/private-ca-with-x-509-name-constraints.html<!----></a><br><br>What is the expected behavior?<span class="line"><!---->What is the expected behavior?<!----></span><br>Name constraint violation certificate error (site certificate is not added by trusted and site CA does not restricted by CA name constraint critical extension)<span class="line"><!---->Name constraint violation certificate error (site certificate is not added by trusted and site CA does not restricted by CA name constraint critical extension)<!----></span><br><br>What went wrong?<span class="line"><!---->What went wrong?<!----></span><br>Browser show valid certificate<span class="line"><!---->Browser show valid certificate<!----></span><br><br>Did this work before? N/A <span class="line"><!---->Did this work before? N/A <!----></span><br><br>Chrome version: 88.0.4324.182  Channel: stable<span class="line"><!---->Chrome version: 88.0.4324.182  Channel: stable<!----></span><br>OS Version: <span class="line"><!---->OS Version: <!----></span><br>Flash Version: <span class="line"><!---->Flash Version: <!----></span><br><br>Firefox works correctly<span class="line"><!---->Firefox works correctly<!----></span><br>RFC: <span class="line"><!---->RFC: <!----></span>https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280#section-4.2.1.10<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280#section-4.2.1.10"><!---->https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5280#section-4.2.1.10<!----></a><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Mar 5, 2021, 12:31 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

        We don't consider this a security threat: An admin who can install a constrained CA is the same as an admin that can install an unconstrained CA ( <span class="line"><!---->We don't consider this a security threat: An admin who can install a constrained CA is the same as an admin that can install an unconstrained CA ( <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<!----></a> )<span class="line"><!----> )<!----></span><br><br>However, more fundamentally, RFC 5280 makes it explicitly clear that a trust anchor, which is the root of trust, is just a name and a key. Implementations are free to use self-signed certificates to represent trust anchors, and when they do, they are also free to respect, or ignore, extensions within. There are a host of design considerations about why it may or may not be appropriate, and as <span class="line"><!---->However, more fundamentally, RFC 5280 makes it explicitly clear that a trust anchor, which is the root of trust, is just a name and a key. Implementations are free to use self-signed certificates to represent trust anchors, and when they do, they are also free to respect, or ignore, extensions within. There are a host of design considerations about why it may or may not be appropriate, and as <!----></span>Issue 1072083<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1072083" title="Feature request: Support constraints on user-imported roots"><!---->Issue 1072083<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>covers, we're aware it's a feature request. However, you should not expect such roots to behave the same across implementations, as covered in the RFC.<span class="line"><!---->covers, we're aware it's a feature request. However, you should not expect such roots to behave the same across implementations, as covered in the RFC.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        >  - I expect this certificate will not affect hosts not satisfying Name Constraint.<span class="line"><!---->&gt;  - I expect this certificate will not affect hosts not satisfying Name Constraint.<!----></span><br><br>Yes, but that's not a reasonable expectation, and not something guaranteed by the spec, nor something that works across a variety of certificate verification implementations. I understand you've tested in certain browser/OS combinations, but across the diverse set of certificate verifiers, what you're looking at is rare.<span class="line"><!---->Yes, but that's not a reasonable expectation, and not something guaranteed by the spec, nor something that works across a variety of certificate verification implementations. I understand you've tested in certain browser/OS combinations, but across the diverse set of certificate verifiers, what you're looking at is rare.<!----></span><br><br>In any event, we don't consider this a bug, let alone a security bug. We're aware that some admins would like the ability to restrict a CA to particular hosts, and so that's why it's treated as a feature request. This isn't solely about nameConstraints - it applies to a variety of conditions (e.g. <span class="line"><!---->In any event, we don't consider this a bug, let alone a security bug. We're aware that some admins would like the ability to restrict a CA to particular hosts, and so that's why it's treated as a feature request. This isn't solely about nameConstraints - it applies to a variety of conditions (e.g. <!----></span>Issue 1143735<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1143735" title="Chrome on Windows does not permit ordinary (i.e. not self-signed) CA certificates to be used as trust anchors"><!---->Issue 1143735<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>Issue 1143729<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1143729" title="Security: Chrome on Android accepts a server certificate that violates the path length constraint in a trusted root CA certificate"><!---->Issue 1143729<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>Issue 1143727<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1143727" title="Security: Chrome treats a certificate in the system trust store as a CA certificate even if it is not a valid CA certificate"><!---->Issue 1143727<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>are just a few examples)<span class="line"><!---->are just a few examples)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Still, I think this is a bug:<span class="line"><!---->Still, I think this is a bug:<!----></span><br><br> - the problem is not reproduced on test certificates when using OpenSSL (as a reference);<span class="line"><!----> - the problem is not reproduced on test certificates when using OpenSSL (as a reference);<!----></span><br> - I checked the default browser and Google Chrome on Android 11, Windows 10, MacOS and Ubuntu 20.04: the problem is reproducible only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04;<span class="line"><!----> - I checked the default browser and Google Chrome on Android 11, Windows 10, MacOS and Ubuntu 20.04: the problem is reproducible only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04;<!----></span><br> - Google Chrome supports Name Constraint if they are not specified on trusted certificate: if the certificate is between trusted and host certificate it's works correctly;<span class="line"><!----> - Google Chrome supports Name Constraint if they are not specified on trusted certificate: if the certificate is between trusted and host certificate it's works correctly;<!----></span><br> - In my case, the Name Constraint extension on the CA certificate is "required" and the client, if it is not supported, must reject everything that is signed by him.<span class="line"><!----> - In my case, the Name Constraint extension on the CA certificate is "required" and the client, if it is not supported, must reject everything that is signed by him.<!----></span><br><br>That is, the problem is reproducible only if the Name Constraint is specified on the trusted certificate and only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04.<span class="line"><!---->That is, the problem is reproducible only if the Name Constraint is specified on the trusted certificate and only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04.<!----></span><br><br>I cannot accept the argument that anyone can install a certificate: you can issue a certificate to a fraud host without access to the device. This makes a targeted attack on the company possible.<span class="line"><!---->I cannot accept the argument that anyone can install a certificate: you can issue a certificate to a fraud host without access to the device. This makes a targeted attack on the company possible.<!----></span><br><br>I understand that different implementations can behave differently. But in this case we are talking about the default browser for the most popular OS (Android).<span class="line"><!---->I understand that different implementations can behave differently. But in this case we are talking about the default browser for the most popular OS (Android).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c14">Comment 14<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Mar 5, 2021, 4:03 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

        Thanks. This will be my last comment, as although I don't think you'll be satisfied with the answer, it remains the correct answer.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks. This will be my last comment, as although I don't think you'll be satisfied with the answer, it remains the correct answer.<!----></span><br><br>OpenSSL is not a useful reference for certificate verification. It does not implement RFC 5280 (or 3280), nor does it implement path building. It is one of the worst references to use for "Internet" client applications, even though its perfectly serviceable as a server.<span class="line"><!---->OpenSSL is not a useful reference for certificate verification. It does not implement RFC 5280 (or 3280), nor does it implement path building. It is one of the worst references to use for "Internet" client applications, even though its perfectly serviceable as a server.<!----></span><br><br>Chrome uses different verification stacks on different platforms, so the differences are expected (as covered in the issue I liked to in <span class="line"><!---->Chrome uses different verification stacks on different platforms, so the differences are expected (as covered in the issue I liked to in <!----></span>Comment #12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->Comment #12<!----></a> and other issues).<span class="line"><!----> and other issues).<!----></span><br><br>Name Constraints don't work like you would like them to, nor have they ever. I can understand this may be surprising and disappointing, but this is perfectly defined, specified behavior. If you install the root certificate, you are trusting the certificates that CA issues. I realize you'd like to only be able to trust "some" of the certificates that CA issues, and that's why <span class="line"><!---->Name Constraints don't work like you would like them to, nor have they ever. I can understand this may be surprising and disappointing, but this is perfectly defined, specified behavior. If you install the root certificate, you are trusting the certificates that CA issues. I realize you'd like to only be able to trust "some" of the certificates that CA issues, and that's why <!----></span>Issue 1072083<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1072083" title="Feature request: Support constraints on user-imported roots"><!---->Issue 1072083<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>is a feature request, but as it stands, and broadly, as it stands in a variety of applications, installing a CA is just that: trusting everything.<span class="line"><!---->is a feature request, but as it stands, and broadly, as it stands in a variety of applications, installing a CA is just that: trusting everything.<!----></span><br><br>Since you're upset about Android behaviour, you'll also be upset to learn that it doesn't respect anything else from the root certificate, including expiration. That, as I covered, is well-defined, well-specified behavior, and the fault is on the client for expecting a different behavior. This same behaviour, which you would find undesired, also helps improve the security of users. For example, see <span class="line"><!---->Since you're upset about Android behaviour, you'll also be upset to learn that it doesn't respect anything else from the root certificate, including expiration. That, as I covered, is well-defined, well-specified behavior, and the fault is on the client for expecting a different behavior. This same behaviour, which you would find undesired, also helps improve the security of users. For example, see <!----></span>https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html"><!---->https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html<!----></a> that was only possible precisely because Android ignores the elements of the root certificates (including Chrome on Android).<span class="line"><!----> that was only possible precisely because Android ignores the elements of the root certificates (including Chrome on Android).<!----></span><br><br>While we may change in the future to support respecting these constraints, at the end of the day, this is not a bug, and certainly not a security bug. Thanks for reporting, and sorry if this answer is dissatisfying.<span class="line"><!---->While we may change in the future to support respecting these constraints, at the end of the day, this is not a bug, and certainly not a security bug. Thanks for reporting, and sorry if this answer is dissatisfying.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 5<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c5">Comment 5<!----></a>

          
        by
        
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Mar 5, 2021, 12:31 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c10">Comment 10<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Mar 5, 2021, 12:31 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        We don't consider this a security threat: An admin who can install a constrained CA is the same as an admin that can install an unconstrained CA ( <span class="line"><!---->We don't consider this a security threat: An admin who can install a constrained CA is the same as an admin that can install an unconstrained CA ( <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/security/faq.md#Why-arent-physically_local-attacks-in-Chromes-threat-model<!----></a> )<span class="line"><!----> )<!----></span><br><br>However, more fundamentally, RFC 5280 makes it explicitly clear that a trust anchor, which is the root of trust, is just a name and a key. Implementations are free to use self-signed certificates to represent trust anchors, and when they do, they are also free to respect, or ignore, extensions within. There are a host of design considerations about why it may or may not be appropriate, and as <span class="line"><!---->However, more fundamentally, RFC 5280 makes it explicitly clear that a trust anchor, which is the root of trust, is just a name and a key. Implementations are free to use self-signed certificates to represent trust anchors, and when they do, they are also free to respect, or ignore, extensions within. There are a host of design considerations about why it may or may not be appropriate, and as <!----></span>Issue 1072083<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1072083" title="Feature request: Support constraints on user-imported roots"><!---->Issue 1072083<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>covers, we're aware it's a feature request. However, you should not expect such roots to behave the same across implementations, as covered in the RFC.<span class="line"><!---->covers, we're aware it's a feature request. However, you should not expect such roots to behave the same across implementations, as covered in the RFC.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>
      </div>

          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>

        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Mar 5, 2021, 1:20 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Fri, Mar 5, 2021, 1:20 PM EST"></chops-timestamp>
        
          <span class="role-label">Project Member</span>

        >  - I expect this certificate will not affect hosts not satisfying Name Constraint.<span class="line"><!---->&gt;  - I expect this certificate will not affect hosts not satisfying Name Constraint.<!----></span><br><br>Yes, but that's not a reasonable expectation, and not something guaranteed by the spec, nor something that works across a variety of certificate verification implementations. I understand you've tested in certain browser/OS combinations, but across the diverse set of certificate verifiers, what you're looking at is rare.<span class="line"><!---->Yes, but that's not a reasonable expectation, and not something guaranteed by the spec, nor something that works across a variety of certificate verification implementations. I understand you've tested in certain browser/OS combinations, but across the diverse set of certificate verifiers, what you're looking at is rare.<!----></span><br><br>In any event, we don't consider this a bug, let alone a security bug. We're aware that some admins would like the ability to restrict a CA to particular hosts, and so that's why it's treated as a feature request. This isn't solely about nameConstraints - it applies to a variety of conditions (e.g. <span class="line"><!---->In any event, we don't consider this a bug, let alone a security bug. We're aware that some admins would like the ability to restrict a CA to particular hosts, and so that's why it's treated as a feature request. This isn't solely about nameConstraints - it applies to a variety of conditions (e.g. <!----></span>Issue 1143735<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1143735" title="Chrome on Windows does not permit ordinary (i.e. not self-signed) CA certificates to be used as trust anchors"><!---->Issue 1143735<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>Issue 1143729<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1143729" title="Security: Chrome on Android accepts a server certificate that violates the path length constraint in a trusted root CA certificate"><!---->Issue 1143729<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>Issue 1143727<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1143727" title="Security: Chrome treats a certificate in the system trust store as a CA certificate even if it is not a valid CA certificate"><!---->Issue 1143727<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>are just a few examples)<span class="line"><!---->are just a few examples)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

          Comment 13<a class="comment-link" href="?id=1185041#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by

        Still, I think this is a bug:<span class="line"><!---->Still, I think this is a bug:<!----></span><br><br> - the problem is not reproduced on test certificates when using OpenSSL (as a reference);<span class="line"><!----> - the problem is not reproduced on test certificates when using OpenSSL (as a reference);<!----></span><br> - I checked the default browser and Google Chrome on Android 11, Windows 10, MacOS and Ubuntu 20.04: the problem is reproducible only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04;<span class="line"><!----> - I checked the default browser and Google Chrome on Android 11, Windows 10, MacOS and Ubuntu 20.04: the problem is reproducible only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04;<!----></span><br> - Google Chrome supports Name Constraint if they are not specified on trusted certificate: if the certificate is between trusted and host certificate it's works correctly;<span class="line"><!----> - Google Chrome supports Name Constraint if they are not specified on trusted certificate: if the certificate is between trusted and host certificate it's works correctly;<!----></span><br> - In my case, the Name Constraint extension on the CA certificate is "required" and the client, if it is not supported, must reject everything that is signed by him.<span class="line"><!----> - In my case, the Name Constraint extension on the CA certificate is "required" and the client, if it is not supported, must reject everything that is signed by him.<!----></span><br><br>That is, the problem is reproducible only if the Name Constraint is specified on the trusted certificate and only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04.<span class="line"><!---->That is, the problem is reproducible only if the Name Constraint is specified on the trusted certificate and only with Google Chrome on Android 11 and Ubuntu 20.04.<!----></span><br><br>I cannot accept the argument that anyone can install a certificate: you can issue a certificate to a fraud host without access to the device. This makes a targeted attack on the company possible.<span class="line"><!---->I cannot accept the argument that anyone can install a certificate: you can issue a certificate to a fraud host without access to the device. This makes a targeted attack on the company possible.<!----></span><br><br>I understand that different implementations can behave differently. But in this case we are talking about the default browser for the most popular OS (Android).<span class="line"><!---->I understand that different implementations can behave differently. But in this case we are talking about the default browser for the most popular OS (Android).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks. This will be my last comment, as although I don't think you'll be satisfied with the answer, it remains the correct answer.<span class="line"><!---->Thanks. This will be my last comment, as although I don't think you'll be satisfied with the answer, it remains the correct answer.<!----></span><br><br>OpenSSL is not a useful reference for certificate verification. It does not implement RFC 5280 (or 3280), nor does it implement path building. It is one of the worst references to use for "Internet" client applications, even though its perfectly serviceable as a server.<span class="line"><!---->OpenSSL is not a useful reference for certificate verification. It does not implement RFC 5280 (or 3280), nor does it implement path building. It is one of the worst references to use for "Internet" client applications, even though its perfectly serviceable as a server.<!----></span><br><br>Chrome uses different verification stacks on different platforms, so the differences are expected (as covered in the issue I liked to in <span class="line"><!---->Chrome uses different verification stacks on different platforms, so the differences are expected (as covered in the issue I liked to in <!----></span>Comment #12<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c12"><!---->Comment #12<!----></a> and other issues).<span class="line"><!----> and other issues).<!----></span><br><br>Name Constraints don't work like you would like them to, nor have they ever. I can understand this may be surprising and disappointing, but this is perfectly defined, specified behavior. If you install the root certificate, you are trusting the certificates that CA issues. I realize you'd like to only be able to trust "some" of the certificates that CA issues, and that's why <span class="line"><!---->Name Constraints don't work like you would like them to, nor have they ever. I can understand this may be surprising and disappointing, but this is perfectly defined, specified behavior. If you install the root certificate, you are trusting the certificates that CA issues. I realize you'd like to only be able to trust "some" of the certificates that CA issues, and that's why <!----></span>Issue 1072083<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1072083" title="Feature request: Support constraints on user-imported roots"><!---->Issue 1072083<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>is a feature request, but as it stands, and broadly, as it stands in a variety of applications, installing a CA is just that: trusting everything.<span class="line"><!---->is a feature request, but as it stands, and broadly, as it stands in a variety of applications, installing a CA is just that: trusting everything.<!----></span><br><br>Since you're upset about Android behaviour, you'll also be upset to learn that it doesn't respect anything else from the root certificate, including expiration. That, as I covered, is well-defined, well-specified behavior, and the fault is on the client for expecting a different behavior. This same behaviour, which you would find undesired, also helps improve the security of users. For example, see <span class="line"><!---->Since you're upset about Android behaviour, you'll also be upset to learn that it doesn't respect anything else from the root certificate, including expiration. That, as I covered, is well-defined, well-specified behavior, and the fault is on the client for expecting a different behavior. This same behaviour, which you would find undesired, also helps improve the security of users. For example, see <!----></span>https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html"><!---->https://letsencrypt.org/2020/12/21/extending-android-compatibility.html<!----></a> that was only possible precisely because Android ignores the elements of the root certificates (including Chrome on Android).<span class="line"><!----> that was only possible precisely because Android ignores the elements of the root certificates (including Chrome on Android).<!----></span><br><br>While we may change in the future to support respecting these constraints, at the end of the day, this is not a bug, and certainly not a security bug. Thanks for reporting, and sorry if this answer is dissatisfying.<span class="line"><!---->While we may change in the future to support respecting these constraints, at the end of the day, this is not a bug, and certainly not a security bug. Thanks for reporting, and sorry if this answer is dissatisfying.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.

        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;

          padding: 0;

          z-index: 999;

          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;

          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;

          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;

            <div>
              <input id="targetProjectInput" aria-owns="chops-autocomplete-1" aria-autocomplete="both" aria-expanded="false" aria-haspopup="listbox" aria-activedescendant="">
              <mr-autocomplete vocabularyname="project" for="targetProjectInput" role="listbox" id="chops-autocomplete-1"><!---->
      <style>
        /*
         * Really specific class names are necessary because ShadowDOM
         * is disabled for this component.
         */
        .chops-autocomplete-container {
          position: relative;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container table {
          padding: 0;
          font-size: var(--chops-main-font-size);
          color: var(--chops-link-color);
          position: absolute;
          background: var(--chops-white);
          border: var(--chops-accessible-border);
          z-index: 999;
          box-shadow: 2px 3px 8px 0px hsla(0, 0%, 0%, 0.3);
          border-spacing: 0;
          border-collapse: collapse;
          /* In the case when the autocomplete extends the
           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */
          margin-bottom: 1em;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tbody {
          display: block;
          min-width: 100px;
          max-height: 500px;
          overflow: auto;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr {
          cursor: pointer;
          transition: background 0.2s ease-in-out;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container tr[data-selected] {
          background: var(--chops-active-choice-bg);
          text-decoration: underline;
        }
        .chops-autocomplete-container td {
          padding: 0.25em 8px;
          white-space: nowrap;
        }
        .screenreader-hidden {
          clip: rect(1px, 1px, 1px, 1px);
          height: 1px;
          overflow: hidden;
          position: absolute;
          white-space: nowrap;
          width: 1px;
        }
      </style>
      <div class="chops-autocomplete-container">
        <span class="screenreader-hidden" aria-live="polite">
          
        </span>
        <table hidden="">
          <tbody>
            
          </tbody>
        </table>
      </div>
    <!----></mr-autocomplete>
            </div>
          </div>

         * is disabled for this component.

           * height of the viewport, we want to make sure
           * there's spacing. */

        for LitElement.

 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
<script type="text/javascript" nonce="">
 runOnLoad(function() {
 if (typeof(ClientLogger) === "function") {
 let cl = new ClientLogger("issues");
 if (cl.started("new-issue")) {
 cl.logEnd("new-issue", null, 120 * 1000);
 }
 if (cl.started("issue-search")) {
 cl.logEnd("issue-search");
 }
 }
 });
</script>
